questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents with severe backache for 10 days and urinary incontinence with a H/O intervertebral lumbar disc prolapse. There is no H/O fever or weight loss. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Cauda Equina syndrome Large disc herniation in the lumbosacral spine with pressure on cauda equina can result in cauda equina syndrome. The symptoms include numbness and weakness in both legs, rectal pain, numbness in the perineum, and paralysis of the sphincters resulting in sudden loss of bowel or bladder control. Causes of Cauda Equina Syndrome: Lumbar disc Herniation, Spinal canal stenosis, Trauma, Abscess, etc. Salient features of Cauda Equina Syndrome: Urinary and bowel incontinence, Perineal anesthesia, Bilateral lower limb weakness, severe backache radiating to lower limbs.

questions.text: Defect in elastic fibers formation lead to all of the following conditions except:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Fractures Elastic fibers or yellow fibers are bundles of proteins (elastin) found in connective tissue and produced by fibroblasts and smooth muscle cells in arteries. Defect in elastic fibers can result in following abnormalities The cardiovascular system in Marfan’s syndrome shows aortic dilatation, aortic regurgitation and aneurysms. Cardiovascular: Cardiomegaly, congestive heart failure, murmurs, cor pulmonale, and aortic aneurysms may occur. Ocular findings include myopia, cataracts, retinal detachment, and superior dislocation of the lens. Gastrointestinal tract: Diverticula of the small and large bowels may be present; rectal prolapse may occur Pulmonary: Bronchiectasis, emphysema, and cor pulmonale may be present. Skeletal: Dislocation of the hips; osteoporosis; and other skeletal abnormalities, such as growth retardation, delayed fontanelle closure, and ligamentous laxity, may be present

questions.text: Which of the following is the most probable cause of painless “Genu varum” in a 2-year-old patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Rickets Rickets is a disease of growing bone that is unique to children and adolescents. It is caused by a failure of osteoid to calcify in a growing person. Osteoid throughout the skeleton is incompletely calciﬁed, and the bone is therefore “softened.” In children there are additional effects on physeal growth and ossiﬁcation, resulting in deformities of the endochondral skeleton (rickets). In active rickets there is thickening and widening of the growth plate, cupping of the metaphysis and, sometimes, bowing of the diaphysis. The metaphysis may remain abnormally wide.

Highyeild:

The given X-ray shows genu varum which is most commonly seen in rickets. In toddlers, bow leg or genu varum is one of the most common initial sign of rickets. In older children, genu valgum or coxa vara might be present. The characteristic features of rickets include: Delayed closure of the fontanelles Frontal bossing Craniotabes - soft skull bones Rickety rosary - enlargement of the costochondral junction Harrison sulcus Pigeon chest or pectus carinatum RADIOLOGICAL FEATURES Radiological features of rickets: Loss of provisional zone of calcification: earliest radiological finding of rickets. Delayed appearance of the epiphysis Widening of growth plate: normal width of growth is 2-4mm. It is increased in cases of rickets due to excessive accumulation of uncalcified osteoid at the growth plate. Cupping of metaphysis: normally metaphysis meets epiphysis as a smooth line of sclerosis. But in rickets the line is absent and the metaphyseal ends appear irregular and the cartilage accumulating in the growth plate creates a depression in the metaphysis causing cupping. Fraying: indistinct margins of the metaphysis Bowing of diaphysis, with thinning of cortices In healing rickets, Zone of calcification becomes denser.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - OPTION A,B AND C ARE NOT THE CORRECT ANSWER

questions.text: Which of the following is the most probable damaged nerve in a patient with supracondylar humerus fracture who is unable to flex interphalangeal joint of the thumb?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Anterior interosseous nerve Flexor polices muscle is responsible for flexion of the thumb at inter-phalangeal joint. FPL is supplied by anterior interosseous nerve which is a branch of median nerve.

Highyeild:

ANTERIOR INTEROSSEOUS NERVE SYNDROME The anterior interosseous nerve can be selectively compressed at the same sites as the proximal median nerve. Common causes Spontaneous (and usually temporary) Physiological failure (Parsonage–Turner syndrome) There is motor weakness without sensory symptoms. The patient is unable to make the ‘OK sign ’ – pinching with the thumb and index finger joints flexed, like a ring – because of the weakness of the flexor pollicis longus and flexor digitorum profundus. Isolated loss of flexor pollicis longus can occur. The condition usually settles spontaneously within a few months. If it does not, surgical exploration and release or tendon transfer may be considered

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - OPTION B,C AND D ARE INCORRECT

Table:

#Mantra RADIAL NERVE 1. Thumb and finger drop 2. Wrist drop 1.Extensors(Posterior interosseous nerve) 2. Extensors of wrist ULNAR NERVE 1. Book test 2. Card test 3. Froment’s sign 4. Egawa test 1. Adductor pollicis 2. Palmar interossei 3. Flexor pollicis substitutes for adductor pollicis 4. Dorsal interossei MEDIAN NERVE 1. Ape thumb 2. Pen test 3. Pincer grasp(Kiloh Nevin Sign) 4. Pointing index (ochners clasp/Benection test) 1. Thenar muscles 2. Abductor pollicis brevis 3. FDP+FPL 4. FDS+FDP(Lateral half of Flexor digitorum profundus)

questions.text: What is the most common cause for the condition given in the image below?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Supracondylar fracture The deformity shown in picture is cubitus varus deformity (also known as “gun stock deformity”) Most common cause of cubitus varus deformity is malunited supracondylar fracture of humerus. It is due to medial and dorsal displacement and internal rotation of distal fragment of supracondylar humerus fracture. Most common cause of cubitus valgus deformity is non-union lateral condylar humerus fracture.

Highyeild:

This fracture is usually caused by a fall on an outstretched hand. The most common age group is 5-10 years Types of supracondylar fracture Extension type: posterior angulation or posterior displacement of distal fragment (95-98%). Flexion type: anterior angulation or anterior displacement of distal fragment. Displacement of the bone Generally, medial displacement of the distal fragment is more common than lateral displacement. Medial displacement of the distal fragment places the radial nerve at risk, and lateral displacement of the distal fragment places the median nerve and brachial artery at risk Mechanism of injury Posterior type - Fall an outstretched hand with hyper extension injury Anterior type - Due to direct violence with the elbow in flexion

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - OPTION A,C AND D ARE NOT THE CORRECT OPTIONS

Table:

#Mantra Gartland's classification for supracondylar fractures Type I: Undisplaced fracture Type II: Partially displaced (posterior cortex is intact) fracture Type III: Completely displaced fracture Type IV: Complete loss of anterior and posterior pariosteal hinge: Unstable in flexion & extension

questions.text: A 55-year-old female came with hip flexor contracture. What is the most likely test to be done in this case?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Thomas test Allis test is used to assess the spasticity or contracture of rectus femoris The Ober’s test evaluates a tight, contracted or inflamed tensor fasciae latae (TFL) and iliotibial band (ITB). Trendelenburg test is used to assess the functioning of abductors of the hip joint. Thomas test is used to check the flexion contracture of the hip joint.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option. A. Allis test The Galeazzi test , also known as the Allis sign, is used to assess for hip dislocation, primarily in order to test for developmental dysplasia of the hip. It is performed by flexing an infant's knees when they are lying down so that the feet touch the surface and the ankles touch the buttocks. Option. B. The Ober's test evaluates a tight, contracted or inflamed Tensor Fasciae Latae (TFL) and Iliotibial band (ITB). The Ober's test must not be confounded with Noble's test and the Renne test, two other tests that are commonly used to detect iliotibial band syndrome. Option. C. Brodie–Trendelenburg test is a test which can be carried out as part of a physical examination to determine the competency of the valves in the superficial and deep veins of the legs in patients with varicose veins.

questions.text: What will be the treatment of choice for the fracture shown in the image below?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Tension band wiring Patella fracture is an avulsion fracture. This occurs due to forceful contraction of quadriceps muscles. The treatment of choice for avulsion fracture is “Tension band wiring”. The principle of TBW is “with eccentric loading, tensile forces are converted into compressive forces.

Highyeild:

Through a longitudinal incision, the fracture is exposed. The fragments are reduced and transfixed with two stiff K-wires; flexible wire is then looped tightly around the protruding K- wires and over the front of the patella. The tears in the extensor expansions are then repaired. A plaster back-slab or hinged brace is worn until active extension of the knee is regained.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - OPTION A: A patellectomy is a surgical procedure to remove the patella (knee cap). A patellectomy can be either a complete patellectomy where the whole patella is removed or a partial patellectomy where only a part of the patella is removed. OPTION C: Intramedullary nailing is surgery to repair a broken bone and keep it stable. The most common bones fixed by this procedure are the thigh, shin, hip, and upper arm. A permanent nail or rod is placed into the center of the bone OPTION D: An external fixation device may be used to keep fractured bones stabilized and in alignment. The device can be adjusted externally to ensure the bones remain in an optimal position during the healing process.

Table:

#Mantra TENSION BAND WIRING A tension band wire is a form of internal fixation used to convert distraction forces into compression forces, promoting bone healing. It is used in Fracture patella Fracture olecranon Fracture greater trochanter Fracture greater trochanter

questions.text: Which of the following is the least useful drug in Rheumatoid arthritis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Febuxostat Febuxostat is the drug used in Hyperuricemia (Gout).

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - OPTION B. Leflunomide is used in the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis and psoriatic arthritis. It helps in slowing down the progression of the disease and provide relief from pain, swelling, and redness. OPTION C. Etanercept is used in the treatment of ankylosing spondylitis, rheumatoid arthritis, psoriasis, ulcerative colitis and Crohn’s disease. It provides relief from inflammation caused due to damaged joints and improves physical function. OPTION: D. Methotrexate is a medicine used to treat rheumatoid arthritis where it can prevent further joint damage. It is also used to treat severe forms of a skin disease called psoriasis by killing cells in the skin which are growing too quickly and to treat tumors in a range of cancers.

Table:

#Mantra Drug Classification NSAIDS: Indomethacin, naproxen, diclofenac, piroxicam, sulindac, etrocoxib Glucocortecosteroids: Prednisolone, methylprednisolone, triamcinolone #JOINTS INVOLVED AND SPARED JOINT DISORDERS COMMONLY INVOLVED JOINTS JOINTS SPARED RHEUMATOID ARTHRITI S PIP, WRIST, MCP, KNEE, SHOULDER, MTP DIP OSTEOARTHRITIS PIP, DIP, 1ST CMC,1ST MTP, HIP, KNEE, SPINE(CERVICAL AND LUMBOSACRAL) MCP, WRIST, ELBOW, ANKLE ANKYLOSING SPONDYLITIS SACROILIAC JOINT , INTERVERTEBRAL JOINTS PSORIATIC ARTHRITIS PIP, DIP RAY DISTRIBUTION
